FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Keisuke Nakamoto visited farms in Ohara looking for ingredients and was inspired by the efforts of farmers working in this region. This prompted his decision to open a restaurant in Kyoto. He studied various food cultures when working as head of the kitchen at a restaurant in Switzerland, and that has led to the originality he demonstrates today. His speciality is a dish of shrimp and beetroot, which uses fermentation to bring out ever new flavours in the ingredients.

Name: Torisaki
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Twisted headbands encircle the brows of the cooks. Owner-chef Tomoki Hata, uchiwa fan in hand, the very picture of his mentor. The dish on offer is yakitori grilled over a close, strong flame, as Hata learned in his apprenticeship. He insists on chicken from Fukushima Prefecture and Kishu-binchotan; skewers are generously sized to enhance the impact of the ingredients. He also takes care to mentor the next generation, such as by sometimes leaving his apprentice in charge of the kitchen.

Name: Kiyama
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The cup of hot water served as soon as you are seated, drawn from a well on the premises, is an essential part of the experience. It holds the key to the flavour of the nimono soup, lovingly prepared by owner-chef Yoshiro Kiyama, as well as in the usucha. The dashi is made in front of guests and is an engaging performance. When comparing the taste of several types of freshly shaved katsuo-bushi and savouring the dashi, you’ll see why this water is a mainstay of everything.

Name: Ichijoji Norihide
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Shoes must be removed,Visa credit card
Description: Hidehito Fukuhara prepares the dashi for cooking vegetables with the utmost care, going all the way to the foot of Hieizan to draw water from a well. The simple dishes are an expression of his sincerity. It was his mentor who taught him old-fashioned Kyoto cuisine. Seasonal dishes include ebi-imo with starchy sauce, steamed sushi and boar stew. What look like simple preparations speak to the skill of a dedicated artisan.

Name: Gosho Iwasaki
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The kaiseki embodies the maxim, ‘cooking makes the person’. Owner-chef Iwasaki’s mature techniques and unforced Kyoto sophistication reveal themselves in his cuisine. In his nabe cooking, he prepares each dish in front of his customers to ensure they don’t miss the fresh-cooked aroma. The beef and slightly bitter taste of edible wild plants in the Spring Bitter Stew put the soul at ease. The rice in an earthenware pot is prepared using Koshihikari rice from his hometown of Kyotamba.

Name: Kyoryori Fujimoto
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: Owner-chef Takashi Fujimoto never wants his customers to get bored, so assembles a menu of kaleidoscopic variety. Egg cockle is dressed in vinegar miso; fugu is seasoned with karasumi, irizake and ponzu, to broaden the range of flavours. The clay-pot rice dishes are richly imaginative, with ingredients such as bamboo shoots with simmered anago and matsutake with soy marinated hamo. Lunch is wonderful, with customers able to choose as many à la carte items as they wish.

Name: cenci
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Born and raised in Kyoto, Ken Sakamoto creates Italian cuisine that refuses to be pigeon-holed. He takes inspiration from Japanese cooking and makes effective use of sansho, shiso flowers, yuzu, and other herbs that lend their aroma to Japanese dishes. The platter of dry-cured ham, in-season vegetables and fresh cheese, all produced in Japan, is a speciality. Sharing the spirit of the producers, he conveys the ingredients' appeal.

Name: Jiki Miyazawa
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The restaurant’s name derives from a cornerstone of Japanese cuisine: fresh ingredients in season (shun no jiki). Jiki Miyazawa is constantly changing how it prepares ingredients, keeping the fare fresh and interesting. For example, the tsukuri is accompanied not with soy sauce but with any of various seasonings, depending on the tsukuri. The rich goma-dofu and the white rice keep regulars coming back for more. The one unchanging feature is good food, lovingly prepared.

Name: Ryoriya Maekawa
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Koichi Maekawa’s goal is to present a ryoriya (‘cookery’) that reflects his taste and personality, unfettered by hidebound tradition. Seasonal vegetables and herbs are prominent in his creations and many of his ideas spring from his experiences as a head chef in Gion. Intent on leaving each customer with happy memories of a fun meal, Maekawa brings his ingenuity to the cuisine with the panache and pride of a craftsman he learned from his mentor.

Name: MUNI ALAIN DUCASSE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Car park,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access
Description: This restaurant is the brainchild of Alain Ducasse, a legend of French gastronomy, whose artistic sensibilities synergise here with the spirit of the ancient capital. The very finest ingredients from Japan and France are used: awabi from Shikoku, wagyu beef from Kyushu, French truffles and lobster. The lightly seasoned fare offers twists on classics. Luxurious surroundings, exquisite cuisine and elegant service welcome you to the world of Alain Ducasse.

Name: Gion Okada
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: There’s something uninhibited in the way Koji Okada and the cooks move around the kitchen – but in harmony, out of which emerges their kappo cuisine. The menu must include a hundred items, so the appeal here is that you can choose freely. Standard items include mackerel oshizushi and nodoguro nitsuke. Ginkgo croquettes are an autumn speciality. Try some nigiri to end. The focus is the ingredients themselves and the food is all about conveying flavours without affectation.

Name: MUNI LA TERRASSE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Car park,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Great view,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Valet parking,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access
Description: A casual restaurant by Alain Ducasse. The cuisine is based on southern French, so it uses plenty of tomatoes and olives, and is both simple yet sophisticated. Dessert features mousse made with chocolate prepared from cacao beans roasted at a Paris chocolatier. The terrace offers unrivalled views of Togetsukyo Bridge and Arashiyama, hence the name “Muni”, Japanese for “unique”.

Name: Enyuan Kobayashi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Tempura kaiseki in the style of this restaurant is a delight to the eyes and a cascade of changing flavours. The tsukuri and soup are a joy, and the interspersal of local vegetables with the tempura dishes is a true Kyoto touch. The tenbara (mixed tempura on rice) at the end is one-of-a-kind. As befits the restaurant’s name, which means a place where people open their hearts to each other, the care and attention of the couple in charge really comes across.

Name: Okina
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Car park,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Okina is run by a father-and-son team, creating a friendly, sociable atmosphere. Tsukuri, tempura, unagi, boiled tofu and deep-fried tofu fritters are all on offer. The charcoal-cooked fare brings out the natural flavour of the ingredients. The tilefish flesh is grilled, and the scales are fried for a pungent aroma. Due to its location in the sightseeing area of Sagano, the restaurant can be busy at lunchtime during peak season, though the pace is more relaxed in the evenings.

Name: Gokomachi Tagawa
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Shoes must be removed,Visa credit card
Description: Born and raised in Mie Prefecture, owner-chef Yoshiaki Tagawa wants his menu to tell stories. For example, the awabi and spiny lobster he sources from a friend in Toba tells of the ways of the ama, the women who free dive for shellfish. Also, harking back, his cuisine showcases the appeal of charcoal grilling. Formerly an engineer, Tagawa longed for a job that involved engaging with people, so switched careers, making his curriculum vitae a story in itself.

Name: Kamigamo Akiyama
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining,Notable sake list
Description: Naohiro Akiyama welcomes customers into an attractive old Japanese-style former house. The counter is his stage, and the curtain rise is his eloquent prologue-like introduction of the menu. The main ingredients are vegetables from Takagamine and seafood from Akashi. Seasonal leaves decorate the hassun, and the rice is cooked on an old-style stove. Curtain fall is the usucha he personally prepares for you. The sincere hospitality will satisfy you to the core.

Name: LURRA˚
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Expect cuisine full of creativity from Jacob Kear. Lurra means ‘the Earth’, ‘the Moon’ and ‘coordinates’ in the Basque language, and indeed this restaurant is a departure point for a trip around the world. Papadams remind you of India, tacos of Mexico, and so on. A chef, a sommelier and a bartender who became close friends in New Zealand form the triumvirate that runs this restaurant with unshakable solidarity.

Name: Muromachi Wakuden
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The rustic yet delicate cuisine of Wakuden can be sampled at the counter here. The chefs banter as they work, letting diners appreciate the energy of the kitchen. The head chef travels regularly to where his ingredients come from to maintain his knowledge of them. In spring he goes to Tsukahara, Kyoto Prefecture, to personally select bamboo shoots. He char-grills these unpeeled or adds them to takikomi-gohan. The respect for their ingredients shines through in the honest flavours of the dishes.

Name: Sushi Rakumi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The chef apprenticed in Japanese cuisine in Kyoto and sushi in Tokyo: “I picked up the best of both Kansai and Kanto”. The vinegared white rice is right at home here in pairings of light-flavoured fish with rice in rice vinegar. For the fattier fishes, he uses rice steeped in akazu, edomae-style. The pièce de résistance is the dish with three pieces of tuna. A tamago-yaki with the aroma of maple syrup completes a meal that is inventive at every turn.

Name: Kentan Horibe
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Tsutomu Horibe was drawn to his gastronomic calling by the way Kyo-ryori reflects seasonal customs. The hassun dishes contain seasonal Zen sayings on long strips of paper, reflecting his reverence for traditional culture. Elegant crockery complements an interior designed in the sukiya style, offering mute instruction on the traditional aesthetics of Japan. The spirit and technique of traditional artisans and the owner-chef’s admiration for them resonate in this space.

Name: AKAI
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Shoes must be removed,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Hiroki Abe constantly researching new ideas in gastronomy and incorporates Western ingredients and cooking methods. His hassun platters are a thing of beauty. In his careful considering of the affinity between ingredients, and his adding of flavours one on top of the other, he creates a unique culinary style.

Name: Gion Fukushi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted
Description: Elegant kaiseki from the skilled hands of an itamae kappo chef. The view of the preparation from the counter seating is as much fun as the cuisine celebrating seasonal events. Gion Fukushi observes these in flamboyant style: the Hina Doll’s Festival with standing Hina dolls and clam bowls  and the Gion Festival with dishes depicting floats. In early summer the ayu is deep-fried and, in a distinctive flourish, sprinkled with kinome vinegar using a tea whisk.

Name: KOKE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Koke means ‘moss’ in Japanese, and, true to its name, the restaurant has a moss garden. It can also stand for ‘Kobe, Okinawa, Kyoto, Español’— to all to which chef Yusaku Nakamura has ties. Spanish cuisine forms the base, but with the use of French culinary techniques. A cornerstone of his cooking is the water from the well in the courtyard and, depending on the ingredients, he will cook over a firewood or charcoal fire, making him a true ‘fire and water chef’.

Name: Funaokayama Shimizu
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Yuki Shimizu opened his restaurant near Daitokuji so that he could use the temple’s clear, pure water. He draws it himself to prepare the dashi and cook vegetables. Daitokuji fu dressed with sesame sauce, a favourite of tea master Sen-no-Rikyu, offers apt tribute to the temple’s shojin ryori. Could his name, Shimizu, which means ‘pure water’, be a sign of his destiny? Certainly, the painstaking effort he pours into his craft deepens the flavour of every dish.

Name: Tempura Mizuki
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Car park,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Notable sake list,Visa credit card,Wheelchair access
Description: The highlight of the tempura is the various kinds of shrimp. First is the usual Japanese tiger prawn. Wrapping certain of the same items in a shiso adds some variation. There are also treats such as seasonal kakiage featuring sakura ebi, Shiba shrimp and Japanese glass shrimp. The speciality is egg yolk tempura topped with caviar. Ending the meal with ornate desserts by Pierre Hermé is something else you’ll only find here.

Name: Gion Kida
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Interesting wine list,Mastercard credit card,Notable sake list,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Yasuo Kida puts his creativity on display with the way he applies heat and uses oils. For example, he coats white asparagus in rice flour and then deep-fries it, and stir-fries edible wild plants in a wok. For seafood tsukuri, he stays true to his principles, eschewing soy sauce in favour of condiments appropriate to each ingredient. He says that he learned from his mentor the importance of letting diners enjoy the flavours, and works hard to achieve that goal with every dish.

Name: La Biographie···
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The counter serves as Masahiro Takimoto's own table. The chef showcases ingredients to be cooked, which he explains while regaling guests with stories from his culinary pursuits. The ‘Egg Chaud-froid’ carries memories of Paris and was passed on to Takimoto by Alain Passard, the chef lauded as the ‘magician of the stove’. Says Takimoto, "I want to be a link in the chain between French cuisine's history and its future."

Name: Ayanokoji Karatsu
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Shosaku Karatsu was deeply impressed by Kyoto foodstuffs and the elegance of Kyo-ryori. Whenever he visits Miyama, he is accompanied by experts on gathering edible wild plants or fishing for ayu, collecting delicacies along the way. Kyo-ryori, a culinary discipline that emerged over centuries of history, is deeply connected to shojin ryori. Karatsu’s use of sesame in his tsukuri and grilled foods is an idea borrowed from Shojin ryori.

Name: Noguchi Tsunagu
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The novel concepts and free-spirited fun here could aptly be referred to as ‘Noguchi-style kappo’. Osaka nikusui (beef soup) is a speciality, prepared with kudzu sauce and seasoned with sansho to give it a Kyoto feel. After the standard five items, you can add others of your choice. Some, like dry-cured duck ham, curry and spring rolls, feature a Western or Chinese element as a key ‘secret ingredient’. This is a restaurant that connects (tsunagu) Kyoto cuisine’s past to its future.

Name: Mejiro Zorome
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The veteran owner-chef uses only unagi caught mainly around Kyushu, as well as brand-name unagi from Shizuoka. The unagi are kept alive in purifying tanks until they are dressed, then dipped three times with sauce and grilled Edo-style. He uses sauce sparingly, to emphasise the flavour. Rice cooked somewhat firm and freshly ground sansho also offer a distinctive touch. The restaurant name means ‘matching dice’, referring to 44, the age at which the owner-chef went independent.

Name: Shokudo Yunoki
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Behind the counter is the owner-chef, who apprenticed at ryotei and ryokan. A favourite on the menu is the plump sardines simmered with ume. Every dish, down to the smoked potato salad and shumai dumplings, is prepared with care. The ceramic chopstick rests are inscribed with the characters for ‘shirafu’, meaning ‘sobriety’. Turn one over and it says ‘chidoriashi’, or ‘drunken staggering’, ‘meitei’, or ‘drunkenness’, and so on – a playful touch reminding you this is a drinking establishment.

Name: AZABU yung
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Shichubo Yung restaurant has supervised a branch whose fare centres on a plentiful variety of à la carte dishes. It’s fun to select from the plethora of dishes enhanced with Asian (particularly Canton) elements. Fragrant steamed shrimp is Hong Kong in style; tomatoes add a tom yam goong feel to dandan noodles; shrimp wontons are seasoned with Thai nam pla. Get close to the action by taking a counter seat, where you can watch the chef in action and hear the clanging of woks.

Name: Tonkatsu Shichijuro
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: Tonkatsu Shichijuro, run by a couple and with an air of friendliness, is loyally supported by regular customers in the neighbourhood. Two types of tonkatsu are served: loin and tenderloin. The pork is coated in crumbs from low-carb bread in order to bring the flavour of the meat to the fore, and slowly deep-fried in lard to boost its umami. The chef’s experience in Japanese cuisine shines in the miso soup made from flavourful katsuo (bonito) dashi and handmade pickles made in bran.

Name: SANTOSHAM
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: ‘Snacks and set meals from southern India’ is the promise at Santosham, where the chef, a native of southern India, and a Japanese couple convey the authentic flavours of the region. The crêpe-like dosa, made from a fermented batter of black gram beans and rice, is soul food. Uttapam, a kind of Indian-style okonomiyaki, is popular. The Shrimp Curry steamed in banana leaves bursts with the unmistakably tropical fragrance of spices and coconuts.

Name: Kurobuta Tonkatsu Horiichi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The family moved to Tokyo from Kagoshima Prefecture to spread the word about the rich, deep flavour of Berkshire pork. Making the rounds of producers in Kagoshima, the couple select their pork with a laser focus on quality. Love of hometown suffuses every item: pickles are marinated in black vinegar from the couple’s native Kirishima, the chef’s mother hand-makes the miso, used in the tonjiru (pork soup), and the sauce captures the flavour of the chef’s parents’ diner back home.

Name: Tempura Otsuka
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The owner-chef, born and raised in Iriya, is an artisan through and through. Proceedings are by the book, starting with milder flavours like tiger prawn, squid and sillago before proceeding to bolder tastes. Edomae toppings are favoured, such as tidepool gunnel and big-eyed flathead. Decorating the walls are senshagaku, wooden tablets typically posted on the pillars of shrines, inscribed with local supporters’ names. The characters suffuse the restaurant with the atmosphere of old neighbourhoods.

Name: L'AS
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The restaurant’s name is French for ‘the ace’, as in ‘ace of the culinary world’. Reading the trends of the modern era, Daisuke Kaneko strives to offer delicious fare at reasonable prices. The menu offers only a single choice for each course, expressed in a simple, modern style. Crispy foie gras sandwiches are Chef Kaneko’s signature dish. Distinctive touches abound, such as vichyssoise with rillettes of ayu on top, served in summer – a reason why it’s so busy, and why so many leave satisfied.

Name: Tonkatsuya Sato
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The owner-chef was born the son of a tonkatsu shop-owner. His preferences in pork are for tender meat and sweet fat. Seeking texture and fragrance, he batters his pork in coarse breadcrumbs. The generous heaps of cabbage are fresh and vibrant, while the plain black crockery frames the tonkatsu majestically. Chicken-katsu is also available. Enjoy with salt, soy sauce or Worcestershire sauce.

Name: HARU CHAN Ramen
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: In Shimbashi Ekimae Building, known as an oasis in the business district, you’ll find the earnest figure of Haru-chan, the female chef. Pop art adorns the walls and billboards symbolise the shop. The ramen is served in a dashi of pork bones and dried sardines and flavoured with salt and lard; the flat noodles have a plump, full texture. A bowl of piping-hot ramen fills the stomach and lends strength for a day’s work.

Name: Kotaro
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Notable sake list,Visa credit card
Description: The pork used in the steamed dumplings and minced cutlets was raised by an acquaintance in the owner-chef’s hometown. He limits the number of breweries he gets his sake from so that he can maintain closer and more meaningful contact. The owner-chef is from Kagawa, a prefecture famous for its udon, so we recommend ending the meal with his homemade-style udon. The full-bodied noodles can be enjoyed with broth or with raw egg and butter poured over them.

Name: D'êtraison
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: This bistro by Kosuke Mita benefits from the chef’s wealth of experience in gastronomy. He delicately tailors his cuisine, adding unique touches. The sauté of shrimp and scallop is curry-flavoured, for example, and beef cheek is offered as a confit. The risotto of Carnaroli rice from Ishikawa Prefecture is a distinctive detail. Mita and his sommelier focus on pairings. The wordless understanding between Mita and his wife make their marriage, and the restaurant, a success.

Name: COMME À LA MAISON
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Yuji Wakui faithfully recreates the cuisine of southwestern France, taught to him by a chef from Landes. From pâté de campagne to terrine de foie gras and duck confit, all are prepared with heartfelt affection. But Wakui reserves a special fondness for soupe de garbure, a simmered mélange of ham, duck, white kidney beans and other ingredients that spreads the flavours of Landes to a ready audience in Tokyo. Unwavering faithfulness to tradition wordlessly expresses Wakui’s gratitude to his mentor.

Name: Nogizaka yui
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The creative Chinese cuisine here is Sichuan-based but with Japanese elements. Whereas Chinese cooking typically uses a lot of cooking oil, Chef Mashiyama exercises great restraint with it. He uses katsuo and kombu dashi in his soups. The theme of Yui is Chinese food adjusted for the Japanese palate, so he dials back the spices in his spicy chicken and mapo tofu. The warm and gracious hospitality of the proprietress and the compelling flavours of the cuisine testify to the couple’s character.

Name: Bistro topology
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The signature dishes are hams and sausages, must-have items for any French dinner table. The charcuterie listed on the blackboard provides a snapshot of the chef’s devotion to his craft. The list runs to 20 or more items at any time, including Grandma’s Paté and Jambon Blanc. ‘Museau’ (snout) is ham made from pork head wrapped in pork cheek and tongue. Home-cooking items such as andouillette and cassoulet also await. This is carnivore heaven.

Name: Bistro Beppinsha
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: The moniker ‘Bistro’ is a nod to owner-chef Shiga’s experience working in a wine bistro. He simmers vegetables in wine, then combines them with spices to make curry. Eschewing flour, he creates flavours that are smooth yet robustly flavourful. The Red, a yakuzen (Chinese medicinal) curry, is pungent with cardamom and ginger, while the Black is a fiery Kashmiri curry. Curries are accompanied by firm-cooked Koshihikari-brand rice.

Name: Lien
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The prix fixe menu dazzles with its range of choices. The chef sources his ingredients from regions with which he is personally connected, mainly from his native Aomori, but also game from Hokkaido. Culinary approaches are varied: terrines, stews and items baked in pie crust are all in the mix. The number of dishes can be increased according to preference. Lien means ‘connection’, a reference to the bonds between guests and producers that are deepened through cooking.

Name: Gimpachitei Yazawa
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only
Description: Toshikazu Yazawa says the true essence of Edo culture lies in soba. Born and raised in Kameari, he has years of experience as a soba artisan. He grinds the buckwheat by hand using a millstone. We recommend the nihachi inaka soba made with that buckwheat flour. In front of the store is the former Mito Highway, used by the famous 17th-century daimyo, Tokugawa Mitsukuni. Note that the soba with natto is called ‘Komon Soba’, named after a popular TV drama.

Name: Nihao
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: The owner-chef learned dim sum from a Chinese artisan during his time training. When he went out on his own, he chose to specialise in boiled, grilled and deep-fried gyoza dumplings. Rather than using minced meat, he chops the pork with a Chinese knife to give it texture. The chewy boiled gyoza is prepared after the order is received. The grilled and deep-fried gyoza are fragrant and juicy and you can order however many you want of each.

Name: Sharikimon Chawambu
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: The chef applies the skills he learned in a kappo to tonkatsu. His customer-focused attitude is on display as he adjusts the amount of fat, the thickness of the meat and so on, according to what the diner wants. Even the seasonings display this individuality. Homemade sauces are heated to bring out the fragrance of the spices, while soy sauce is made into kaeshi (dipping sauce) and accompanied by mustard. Heated sauce is poured on the accompanying curry, to finish the meal with a curry rice.

Name: Tonkatsu Enraku
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: The veteran owner-chef has devoted his life to tonkatsu pork cutlets. As he fries pork loin and tenderloin, he concentrates on the changing colour of the coatings and the hiss of oil in the copper pot. Cabbage is chopped by hand as the pork sizzles. Deft, precise movements calculated with the final result in mind fill guests with anticipation. This is craftsmanship learned the old-fashioned way, through patient repetition of the master’s lessons. Bookings are accepted for weekday evenings.

Name: PST Roppongiten
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: PST stands for Pizza Studio Tamaki, and the Tamaki-style is to emphasise the fragrance and saltiness of the crust. Salt is shaken into the furnace to give the bottom of the crust a hint of saltiness and bring out the sweetness of the flour. The edges are fully baked until fragrant. The chef has come up with his own flour mix for maximum lightness. He also doesn’t over-knead the dough, but lets it form naturally to give the crust some variation in texture.

Name: UNE PINCÉE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: This à la carte French restaurant in Higashi-Azabu is counter-service style, in keeping with Chef Mahori’s desire for people to enjoy French cuisine casually. The relaxed vibe also shows in the à la carte items for sharing, the risotto and pasta items to finish, and even the French music. His light touch with seasonings is a strong point. Just a pinch of seasoning (‘une pincée’ in French, hence the restaurant’s name) is enough to draw out the flavour.

Name: Shiomachi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The owner-chef visits fishmongers at Toyosu Market and trades information with brokers. He bases his culinary ideas on the day’s catch. Drained of blood to preserve freshness, the fish may be served as tsukuri, for example, or sakamushi. Encouraging patrons to enjoy their fare with sake, Shiomachi offers a range of shuko, such as shiokara (paste made from salted fermented seafood) or monkfish liver. As a man who treasures his encounters with each day’s catch, the owner-chef must be barely able to wait for morning.

Name: Osteria da K. [káppa]
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Sauté of golden cuttlefish; oyster risotto; seafood ragù – the wealth of fish dishes kindles the appetite. The secret to Osteria da K.’s superb seafood is its unusual pedigree: think of it as an Italian restaurant opened by a sushi chef and you’ll understand. Moreover, the chef is well-versed in the art of handling fish. The osteria-style à la carte dishes are simple, focused squarely on ingredients. Being a casual eatery in Ginza, it is crowded night after night.

Name: Andagyoza
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The speciality here is healthy boiled gyoza dumplings, offered in four varieties. Light on the stomach, the fillings include ginger, Szechuan pickles and curry. As no garlic or Chinese chives are used, they won’t stay on the breath, and this makes them popular with diners. If you want to try all of them, we recommend the teishoku. There are also some unique items such as wood ear mushroom stew and mapo tofu made without oil.

Name: estación
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The name of the restaurant means ‘seasons’ in Spanish, and the focus is on seasonal ingredients. The main offering is a set menu that combines regional Spanish cuisine with Japanese ingredients. Examples include dishes made with ayu and gazpacho featuring eggplant and peaches. They offer traditional meat dishes and rice dishes such as lamb asado and seafood arroz meloso. There is a blend of two food cultures here, making the most of nature’s bounty.

Name: KYORIN
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Inoue inherited this kappo from his father. He learned the art of making soba from a relative, and welcomes customers with a selection of shuko, a product of his studies in Japanese cuisine. He adjusts the ratio of buckwheat flour in his soba based on the condition of the flour and the climate. The key factor in the dipping sauce is the generous amount of katsuo-bushi used in the dashi. As Inoue was born and raised here, his restaurant is a popular choice with local diners.

Name: Yuge
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: Steamed pork dumplings, cut and pounded by hand; spring rolls stuffed with shrimp – Yuge’s no-nonsense cooking testifies to its passion for Chinese cuisine. The owner-chef learned his skills at a cooking school, where his mentor taught him to keep it simple. Stir-fried bitter melon in summer and spicy tofu with shirako in winter exemplify this approach of simple, honest preparations of fresh ingredients in season. Home-style flavours leave a lasting impression.

Name: SŌWADŌ
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Sowado is just past Ebisu Bridge, which crosses the Shibuya River, but there is no sign. Pass through a cheerless grey corridor, then be greeted by cooks in crisp whites working in a lively interior. The eye is drawn to the ‘Genshiyaki’, skewers of fish and meat grilled slowly over a charcoal brazier as in ancient times. We recommend the dishes with which the chef feels a special connection: Unzen ham cutlet, nanbanzuke and steamed squid dumpling, for example. All are from Kyushu.

Name: Sobaya Moriiro
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted
Description: Owner-chef Masashi Tsuchiya travels from one producing region to the next in search of high-quality buckwheat. He talks to producers regularly, even participating in sowing and harvesting the crops. He eschews fixed ratios of buckwheat and wheat, preferring to adjust according to the condition of the buckwheat. Remarkably, he prepares the noodles separately by producing region. The dipping sauce, with its rich aroma of bonito flakes, further enhances the flavour of the noodles.

Name: Noto Kanazawanosachi Ginza Furuta
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The couple in charge of this restaurant want to tell the world about the wealth of food from Ishikawa Prefecture. Fish arriving from Nanao, the proprietress’ place of birth, is prepared by her husband, the owner-chef. In addition to vinegared mozuku seaweed and rosy sea perch cooked whole, the restaurant serves mountain treats such as vegetables from Kaga and edible wild plants from the Noto Peninsula. The couple tour farms and sake breweries, building warm relations with producers.

Name: Concerto
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: While based on Italian, the dishes are unique in their use of domestic ingredients such as seaweed and citrus fruits. An example of this is the hamo fritters with ume sauce. As the name ‘Concerto’ suggests, you’ll be treated to a harmonious performance by chef Iguchi, the conductor, and sommelier Harada, the concert master. The Italian dishes, Japanese ingredients, and wine from various countries come together to create a symphony.

Name: Konakara Honten
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Shoes must be removed,Visa credit card
Description: There is a twentieth century feel to this restaurant with its counter seating and big gourd-shaped copper pot. Customers sit shoulder to shoulder here, enjoying oden around that pot. Expect Kansai-style oden featuring dashi made from katsuo-bushi, kombu, shiitake and other ingredients. There are many ingredients, including daikon, eggs, potato dumplings and pumpkin dumplings. Popular in winter is the oyster soup.

Name: Daikanyama Issai Kassai
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The atmosphere is modern, as befits the establishment of an owner-chef who honed his gastronomic senses in New York. Subdued lighting illuminates the counter and his experience shines in the cuisine, which is playful and imaginative. The famed potato salad is loaded with smoked and simmered eggs and thick-cut bacon. The Tsumami Nabe served in small pots was conceived as an accompaniment for drinks. Spring clams are simmered in katsuo dashi and drizzled in ginjo (high-quality) sake for fragrance.

Name: Bistrot Vivienne
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Standard fare includes quiche, pâté de campagne and stews. The concept is ‘the kitchen next door’, inspired by the owner sommelier’s memories of her days living in Paris. Recipes are creations of a seasoned chef steeped in the arts of gastronomy, as attested by meat dishes with sauce and items baked in pastry. An extensive wine list completes the bistro’s French ambience.

Name: Tompachitei
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: This shop in Ueno’s Tanuki-koji area opens only for lunch. The tonkatsu, rich in pork-fat aroma, follows a recipe passed from generation to generation. The reason for its loyal following is the work hidden in the batter: when an order is received, the pork is pounded, lightly scored and cooked on a low flame, give the cutlets their distinctive flavour. The pickled vegetables, marinated in a salted-rice-bran bed passed down through generations, play a great supporting role.

Name: Grace
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning
Description: The name of the restaurant comes from the fact that during Korea’s dynastic period, only monarchs could eat samgye-tang. The owner visited many samgye-tang restaurants in the localities out of a desire to recreate the authentic taste. Following tradition, he uses raw ginseng and jujube. In South Korea, samgye-tang is considered a yakuzen. Ginger tea is served after the meal for its warming effect, based on a balanced diet promoting good health.

Name: falò
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The char-grilled items are the main draw at this ‘open-fire (falò) Italian’ eatery. Chef Kashimura was captivated by the dramatic sight of sizzling chunks of meat and the flavour of the meat at the first barbecue he experienced. The fish warayaki, scorched as if smoked in burning straw, is a favourite, as is the porchetta, slow-grilled for over an hour. The subtle fragrance of charcoal enfolds the ingredients. Seating is arranged as if customers are sitting around a bonfire.

Name: LA BOTTEGAIA
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The owner switched careers from chef to sommelier after becoming fascinated with Italian wine. In homage to the trattoria he once frequented, the owner named his restaurant ‘Bottegaia’, which means ‘shopkeeper’. There are no standard dishes, as the chef emphasises a sense of the season. He gives free rein to his creative urges, serving spaghetti with ayu and green chilli pepper in summer, and foie gras with daikon in winter.

Name: Hibino Chukashokudo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: As the name ‘Everyday Chinese Diner’ suggests, the concept is an eatery where you can drop in every day. To encourage locals to visit, teishoku are available for lunches. At dinner, combinations of small bowls, presenting a wide variety of flavours, are popular. The pride of the head chef, who cut his teeth in Sichuan and Canton, is the crispy chicken. Dim sum can be ordered from as little as a single item. The contrast between the casual atmosphere and the chic interior is part of the appeal.

Name: Le Bouton
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Cuisine tailored to the season and bistro-style home cooking await the diner here. The red king crab salad combines colourful, shredded seasonal vegetables accented with the texture of crisps.  The mains include duck confit and boudin noir. The freedom to choose your trimmings is a nice touch. There’s also a secret menu, inspired by customers’ wishes, you’ll discover when you arrive, which is part of the fun.

Name: Bangera's Kitchen
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Here you can enjoy authentic flavours rich with the fragrance of spices and coconut, as this restaurant specialises in the local cuisine of the southern Indian port town of Mangalore. The standard offerings are dishes made using seafood, such as tai, buri and sawara, with the kinds of seasoning used in Mangalore. Cooking methods include tandoor grilling, frying and masala sauce.

Name: Chukasoba KOTETSU
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: The name ‘Kotetsu’ was Tetsuya Oshima’s nickname as a child. He trained at a restaurant specialising in pork broth with soy sauce, but for his own place he chose Chinese noodles to appeal to a broader customer base. He uses three kinds of dried fish shavings to make the dashi and adds fish sauce made from squid to the kaeshi to give it more depth. The thin noodles have little water content and remain firm. Order the backfat topping if you enjoy the sweetness of pork fat.

Name: Sennomago
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only
Description: True to his motto that the way to good health is through a balanced diet, Soda wields his Chinese cooking pots to create dynamic cuisine. Based on Sichuan and Shanghai culinary traditions, he whips up unique flavours using seasonings prepared from Chinese herbal medicine. Diners can choose how their fish is cooked, and with which seasonings; vegetable cuisine is prepared using crops raised by his family in Oita. Soda lets his individuality run especially free with the mapo dofu.

Name: you-en
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Ouchi takes a freewheeling approach to interpreting Chinese cuisine. The Uni Yuba appetiser is a speciality of uni marinated in Shaoxing wine and served on a yuba mousse. The popular Mao Zedong spareribs and black fried rice are essentials for the ‘secret menu’. The name, using characters for ‘play’ (‘yuu’) and ‘monkey’ (‘en’), refers to the kitchen as ‘a playground born in the Year of the Monkey’. It is also a play on Chef Ouchi’s desire to establish a connection (en) with you (yuu).

Name: AlCeppo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: AlCeppo presents cuisine from every part of Italy. In spring and summer, offerings include vegetable frites and salad of octopus from the south and karasumi. Autumn and winter bring stews of meat and fish, befitting the north of the country. Hometown cooking in tune with the climate and prepared with generous amounts of seasonal ingredients is the recurring theme here. Having worked together for many years, the team of chef and a service staff member serve up authentic flavours.

Name: Mono-bis
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Mono-bis proclaims a new concept in French cuisine: ‘French Gozen’, a fusion of Japanese teishoku (set meal) and French prix fixe. Dishes such as Bouillabaisse Gozen and Hamburg Rossini Gozen fill the menu. Dinner starts with a consommé as the appetiser. Main dishes come with butter rice or seasonal takikomi-gohan. Following the Japanese culinary format puts diners at ease.

Name: BARBE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The French word barbe means ‘beard’. The chef, a devotee of classic cuisine, places great store by his sauces, preparing separate chicken and beef consommés and making sauces of port and madeira. Wines are selected from the cellar and offered at reasonable prices, which is a blessing. The moustachioed chef and sommelier prepare foie gras macarons to greet customers.

Name: Katsuo Shokudo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: Inspired by her grandmother’s miso soup and the sight of her making fresh bonito shavings, Mai Nagamatsu is telling the world about the wonders of katsuo-bushi. In constant search of the best bonito, she tours producing regions and visits fishermen. Generous portions of fresh bonito shavings are heaped on top of rice and served with miso soup. She thanks each departing customer with her trademark farewell, Arigatsuo! – expressing gratitude that springs from her grandmother’s love.

Name: noura
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: This bistro is supervised by the owner Arai of HOMMAGE. In the kitchen is Chef Matsumoto, who spent time together with him in France. They prepare traditional dishes without excess. Standard offerings include pâté de campagne, smoked salmon and steak and fries. The Asakusa roots show in such touches as serving a rice dish at the end.

Name: Tonkatsu Hasegawa
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Sangenton pork is a cross between three breeds of pig. The owner-chef was particularly impressed by the product of a Sangenton pork especially those produced by farmers in Tochigi. You get to enjoy it three times, first with wasabi and rock salt, then with oroshi ponzu and finally with tonkatsu sauce. Giving the assortments of loin, tenderloin, croquettes and other items names like ‘Yokozuna’ and ‘Ozeki’ is very Ryogoku, reflecting the area’s strong sumo presence.

Name: The Pizza Bar on 38th
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Car park,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The marble counter taking inspiration from its name Pizza Bar seats eight. The dough is made from organic Italian wheat and takes two days to mature. The crust is moist, lending it a light texture. Service is à la carte at lunch, and prix fixe offerings for all seats at once in the evening. Eight pizzas are baked one after another, so guests can try eight varieties before dessert. Hotel guests take precedence, so reservations may be difficult to secure.

Name: DIALOGUE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Cooking is a game of catch, a dialogue between souls. Hence the name of this restaurant, a conversation between the cuisine of Chef Yoshii and the wines of sommelier Shimokawa. Familiar French dishes for the day are written on a blackboard for all to see. The duck and foie gras baked in pie pastry and the vegetable terrine are listed year-round. The fun of choosing and the joy of tasting stimulate conversation, bringing hearts together.

Name: LAUBURU
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Chef Shinichiro Sakurai has undying affection for Basque cuisine. During his time in France, he found his calling in the country cooking that drew him the most. The pork dishes listed on the blackboard consist solely of items Sakurai loves to cook, such as brawn, confit of shank, and char-grilled pork loin. The time and toil he devotes to each dish are testament to the respect and passion he feels for the Basque Country.

Name: Sobamae Nagae
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining,Notable sake list
Description: The owner-chef studied Japanese cuisine and soba-making, aiming to open a restaurant where people could enjoy both food and sake. He visits breweries regularly to build dialogue with the producers. We recommend starting with an elaborate delicacy and sake and ending with nihachi or inaka soba. Grilled miso and itawasa are must-try appetisers for the soba. The rich, fermented flavour of the pickles made in bran paste and vegetables with salted rice malt goes well with sake.

Name: Soba Tajima
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The allure of Soba Tajima lies in its rich selection of à la carte items. The chef puts special effort into the vegetable dishes. Set menus allow diners to choose the dishes they like, and thoughtfully, you can also adjust their number. Diners can also order more helpings of the soba that ends the meal. And of course, orders for just a plate of soba are cheerfully accepted. Both the standard snacks for a soba shop, and sake offerings that change with the season, are worth anticipating.

Name: CRAZY PIZZA at SQUARE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: ‘A diner you’ll want to visit every day’ is the concept here. Atop Chef Shibata’s  pizza crusts, a culinary exchange goes on every day between the gastronomies of Japan and Italy. The Mayo Corn is an old Japanese standby—a corn and mayonnaise pizza , typical Japanese. Cinque Formaggio uses generous amounts of five different Italian cheeses, while another speciality is an original pizza smothered in toppings stewed the way Shibata learned in Italy. Mix and match for a medley of delightful tastes.

Name: Ametsuchi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining,Notable sake list
Description: The Showa-era décor, lit with incandescent bulbs, soothes the soul, while the name combines ‘rain’ and ‘soil’ – essential elements for growing vegetables. Owner-chef Miho Doi, whose parents hail from Kansai, was brought up in a region where light soy sauce is preferred. The dashi enhanced with ma-kombu also reflects this lighter seasoning. She cooks food that pairs well with sake, calling herself a ‘warmed-sake advocate’. The sake is junmai-shu, a pleasing companion when heated just so.

Name: YAKUMO
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: ‘Yakumo’ is the name of the owner-chef’s hometown. Opening a wonton noodle restaurant kind of made sense, with the first Chinese character in ‘wonton’ and the character for ‘kumo’ happening to be the same. For the soup, you can choose between ‘Shirodashi’ made with white soy sauce or ‘Kurodashi’ made with dark soy sauce. If you can’t decide which to order at the ticket machine, just press either one and just ask for a ‘mix’, and free yourself from agonising over it!

Name: Tonkatsu Narikura
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The pork cutlets, refined through a process of tinkering and improvement, are surprisingly light-coloured, thanks to coating in low-carb breadcrumbs and frying at low heat. The pork juices cling to the delicate batter, not going to waste. In addition to loin, tenderloin and belly, there’s even a mille-feuille cutlet. The chef’s approach is trial-and-error: time-consuming and with mistakes along the way, but the result is success. A unique tonkatsu born of theory, experience and instinct.

Name: Gyozabo Chohakkai
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: Here you can enjoy the different flavours and textures of gyoza dumplings prepared by either frying, steaming or boiling, or without the use of garlic. The chef, from Harbin in China, conveys the authentic Chinese cuisine and her speciality is the pan-fried gyoza dumpling called ‘Hanagyoza’. There are also creative dishes such as ‘Shojin steamed gyoza’ with vegetable filling and ‘Sichuan-style spicy boiled gyoza’.

Name: Sushidokoro Shigeru
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: With his restaurant, the chef depicts a local unassuming sushi shop. The small counter fosters an air of kinship, as does the friendly service. His conviction shows in the meticulous care he pours into each item. Dishes are not only salted, marinated and simmered, they are prepared with knife techniques so practiced as to seem effortless, then formed by hand to finish. An omakase set menu with snacks is on offer, but the focus here is on nigiri sushi, what a sushi shop originally was.

Name: Urokogumo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: ‘Urokogumo’ means ‘cirrocumulus clouds’ and comes from the restaurant having opened in autumn under cloudy skies. ‘Uroko’ alone means ‘scaly’, and, sure enough, the restaurant specialises in fish. We recommend the sashimi, which comes with a great variety. The standard offerings are chawanmushi with shellfish dashi, and the crab cream croquettes. There are also shuko like liquor-soaked roasted cornetfish kobujime and shimesaba and ginger wrapped in nori.

Name: Le Monde Gourmand
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: What gives this small bistro its warmth is surely the personalities of the husband-and-wife team. The many dishes also have universal appeal and include pâté en croûte, fish in pie pastry and roast lamb. Using techniques learnt in Southern France and Paris, Chef Takashi Kato has an eye for modern sensibilities, so keeps the dishes light. He says his support is from those living nearby, which is no surprise.

Name: Les Copains de DOMINIQUE BOUCHET
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Credit card / Debit card accepted
Description: This bistro is the vision of chef Dominique Bouchet, a lifelong disciple of gastronomy, and his philosophy of enhancing simple cuisine with delicious elements. The focus here is on sauces, the foundation of his cuisine. Dugléré sauce, redolent of herbs and tomatoes, poured over fish poêlé, and steak frites paired with rich, sweet port trace Bouchet’s culinary journey.

Name: BRAMASOLE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Kenta Takahashi was charmed by olive oil drenched in the Mediterranean sun. The restaurant’s name means ‘one yearning for the sun’, referring to Takahashi himself. One taste of his dishes made with olive oil will convince you of his expertise in the subject. The house speciality is the fennel and sardine pasta. Ever eager to please his guests, Takahashi will even prepare items not on the menu. Taking the freedom of à la carte one step further is one of the joys of Bramasole.

Name: Cristiano's
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Portuguese cuisine seems distant yet familiar to Japanese people. The word ‘Takoten’ is often heard in kitchens and dining halls and refers to the octopus fritters that recreate the local tastes of Portugal and is also the roots of tempura. Local wine brings out the flavour of this local-style cuisine – flavours that win over the local palate with tastes that seem somehow familiar. The owner-chef’s speciality is bacalhau (dried cod).

Name: Tohakuan Karibe
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Using European chairs in an otherwise Japanese atmosphere sets this dining room apart. The décor suggests a bamboo grove, recalling owner-chef Masakazu Karibe’s apprenticing days. He grinds unpolished buckwheat from Nagano and Niigata Prefectures finely, crafting soba noodles that are silky-smooth. Sobagaki squeezed into balls using a cloth tastes velvety smooth. The signature tempura soba at his mentor’s place so deeply impressed him that it confirmed his decision to apprentice as a soba chef.

Name: Chukasoba Nishino
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: ‘Nishino’ is not the owner-chef’s name - uniquely, the place is named after a young female pop star with whom he is infatuated. The menu carries only two items, ramen and sansho (Japanese pepper) ramen. Seeking a flavour similar to udon dashi, he creates soup by mixing dried-sardine dashi with white soy-based sauce. His devotion shines in the Narutomaki fish cake, which forms a hiragana no (の). Listening to girl-band tunes while slurping noodles is this shop’s one-of-a-kind experience.

Name: T'astous
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: ‘Bistronomy’ is the concept here: more modern than a bistro, more gastronomy than cooking. Owner-chef Tsuyoshi Horie named his restaurant after a French dialectical word for ‘as you like it’. Patrons can choose prix fixe or à la carte dining. Use of pesticide-free vegetables and natural wine reflects Horie’s emphasis on the natural. Enjoy a dining experience that is neither bistro nor restaurant.

Name: Tachigui Sushi Tonari
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: A chic stand-up sushi bar in the style of a standing bar. The restaurant shows great inventiveness in the sweet and sour vinegared rice and combinations of toppings. In addition to the typical tuna and gizzard shad, sushi topped with eggplant agebitashi (deep-fried, then soaked in dashi) or red bean paste are available. Reservations, orders and billing are all managed on a digital system. A sushi shop that began as a street stall in Edo ties is reborn in a version fit for today’s Japan.

Name: Kuhara
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Enjoy the conversation of the proprietress and the owner-chef’s devotion to his cooking. Don’t miss snacks like simmered oysters with mizansho and fukinoto (giant butterbur) miso. The pièce de résistance is the duck cuisine. In summer, duck breast is simmered and served cold; in winter, jibuni is presented hot. For vegetables, the inspiration is shojin ryori (vegetarian fare derived from Buddhist monks’ dietary restrictions). Kokushojiru is miso soup bursting with the umami of root vegetables.

Name: DA PEPI
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Owner-chef Nonaka’s passion is the village cuisine of Tuscany. His inspiration came when, on a trip to Italy, he tasted home cooking in a small town and was instantly smitten. The Carrettiera is pasta in tomato sauce seasoned with garlic and chilli pepper, while the Ribollita is a stew of bread, lentils and generous amounts of vegetables. Prizing simplicity, Nonaka conveys the flavours of rural Tuscany, accentuated with a touch of salt.

Name: Tempura Kakiage Yukimura
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: “I wanted people to be able to enjoy tempura casually”, explains owner-chef Tsuji, a fan of Japan’s hawker culture, so he opened a restaurant that draws men and women of all ages to come regularly, eschewing set menus in favour of teishoku and bowls of rice with toppings. The famous kakiage over a bowl of rice comes loaded with shrimp. The kakiage bowl is also made available on the dinner menu; the attentive service makes you feel at ease.

Name: La Boucherie Goûtons
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Boucherie means ‘butcher shop’ in French and this bistro specialises in pork dishes from France, including homemade charcuterie, chargrilled bone-in loin and Panko-breaded grilled pig’s trotters; all made using Shizuoka pork. The chef serves mostly regional dishes he learned how to make in France. The cassoulet is a winter delight featuring stewed white kidney beans and pork.

Name: Kirimugiya Jinroku
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only
Description: The owner-chef pursues his own take on udon that is neither Sanuki nor Inaniwa. He serves the noodles freshly made and just boiled to make sure they are full-bodied and chewy. He says that stretching the noodles before boiling gives them just the right chewiness. The ‘Oyakoten’, which features chicken and egg tempura on top, is a popular choice. At dinner, various shuko are offered so you can enjoy appetisers specifically for udon.

Name: IBAIA
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Char-grilled meat on the bone and homegrown vegetables  are the main attractions at this bistro. Though it launched as a Basque restaurant, the turning point came when, at customers’ behest, it started serving cutlets of beef tenderloin. All eyes turn when the chef lights the grill: the thick chunks of char-grilled meat are the stars of the show. To give time for it to cook slowly till it falls off the bone, frites of Brussels sprouts and seasonal vegetable dishes are an enjoyable warmup act.

Name: BistroCaniche
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The owner-chef learnt broadmindedness from his years of training in French cuisine. He was inspired, too, by the food culture of pursuing originality while emphasising tradition. His speciality is bouillabaisse. The rich soup brings out the flavour of fragrantly grilled seafood, and the leftover soup is used to make risotto. The seasonal terrines are unique, featuring ingredients such as barracuda and eggplant or crab and Chinese cabbage.

Name: Edosoba Hosokawa
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only
Description: Chef Hosokawa tours producing regions in search of the highest-quality buckwheat. He kneads his soba noodles reverently and you can compare buckwheat from different regions, tasting the unique character the terroir impart to each. The spring ‘Wakatake’ with bamboo shoots and wakame is fragrant with the aroma of young pepper leaves. In summer, ‘Hiyakaki’ includes the luxury of large oysters. Visiting to taste the soba of each season is one of the pleasures of Edosoba Hosokawa.

Name: Shizuru
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The husband-and-wife team provide warm hospitality, and the reasonable pricing speaks of their personable ways. Based on the chef’s experience with kaiseki cuisine, seasonal flowers are arranged, and the chopsticks are wetted out of respect for traditional etiquette. While adding an extra touch to items such as the hassun and soups, the chef lets the natural flavours speak. Chargrilled specialities like tilefish and ayu are also a treat.

Name: Shunsai Oguraya
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Makoto Horiuchi was born into a family that ran a yoshoku restaurant. He started down that same path but came to long for the stately, commanding presence of a high-end Japanese cuisine chef. The restaurant uses quality seafood from the Naruto Strait and he prepares tai, shrimp, hamo and other ingredients as tsukuri or grilled. ‘Shunsai’ means ‘vegetables of the season’; he sources them from his home prefecture of Yamanashi and makes them into ohitashi and takiawase.

Name: SHIROKANE chez tomo Natural Cuisine
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: ‘Natural cuisine’ here means ‘food raised by nature and prepared using French techniques’. The organic-wheat bread to start conveys the chef’s commitment to nature. The Nama Uni no Kifujin-fu harmonises scrambled eggs with sauce américaine. In the mixed platter of organic vegetables from Yamanashi Prefecture, each vegetable is prepared in a different style. All menu items here are specialities the chef has been creating for years.

Name: Sasaki Seimenjo
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Counter dining
Description: Chef Sasaki’s ideal is simply, “everything is delicious”. Such a great statement! With ‘seimenjo’, or ‘noodle factory’, in the name, his use of Japanese wheat is definitely a selling point. Out of love for his home region, he uses salt and soy sauce sourced from Akita Prefecture. Clear soup of chicken and seafood seems somehow nostalgic. The goal is to be a restaurant that yearns for its home region. Produce is purchased from nearby shops, so as Sasaki Seimenjo prospers, so does Nishiogikubo.

Name: TROMPETTE
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Retro posters and antique furniture grace this intimate bistro, where the apron-clad chef works alone. What Kenji Yamada serves up here is honest, traditional French fare. From his experiences walking around trying the food at bistros in Paris and bouchons in Lyon, Yamada serves hearty portions. If you come in the evening, we recommend the pigeon and foie gras baked in pie pastry, a classic dish.

Name: Bistro Tatsumi
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: The chef’s forte is les abats (offal cuisine), which has long been popular in France. Encountering this cuisine during his apprenticeship in France, he was attracted by its depth and the skill it requires. His fare conveys the deliciousness not only of beef and pork liver but also of offal such as ears and feet. The speciality is Abats Gelés, a dish of honeycomb tripe and beef sinew in a jelly of pig’s-feet extract.

Name: IRUCA TOKYO
FacilitiesAndServices: Cash only,Counter dining
Description: The owner-chef discovered an original soup by researching synergistic effects with umami. Blending dashi from chicken, pork, shrimp and shellfish, he created a soup with layer upon layer of umami. His ‘Porcini Soy-sauce Ramen’ features a fragrant paste of porcini mushrooms and black truffles. ‘Salted Yuzu Ramen’ transforms the soup with ginger and spices for a modern sensibility.

Name: O2
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Chef Otsu aims to create a new form of Chinese cuisine. Not limiting himself to regions such as Szechuan or Shanghai, he incorporates elements from other countries, too. Examples include seasonal steamed dumplings featuring wild vegetables and corn and monaka wafer cake filled with confit-style ayu. Beef cheek with fermented black bean stew is a standard meat dish. Traditional items make their appearance in the set menu as well, giving variety to the meal.

Name: Teuchisobadokoro Shisen-an
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,Cash only,Notable sake list
Description: This restaurant is in a residential area some distance from the station. A remodelled home, it has a nostalgic feel to it. The flavoursome buckwheat berries come primarily from Fukui and Ibaraki, and the mellow sauce goes well with the soba. Start with the seiro soba or kake soba to enjoy the essential flavour of the ingredients. There is also a wide selection of appetisers, including anago nikogori and roast duck.

Name: Osobano Kouga
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Here, you’ll be spellbound by the various soba dishes, including the uni speciality, hamo and water shield in the summer and oysters in winter. Hiroshi Kouga’s creativity is driven by his inquisitive spirit. While training at an established restaurant, he was taught that combining raw seafood is strictly forbidden with Edo soba, and this guideline became a new turning point for him. The basic offering is toichi seiro and salty-sweet soup.

Name: Kinoshita
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Cash only - lunch,Counter dining,Diners Club credit card,Interesting wine list,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Jellied pork, soupe de poisson, beef simmered in red wine – filled with respect for classic French cuisine, the chef is keen to serve dishes that warm the soul. The style is universal yet prepared with a unique touch, honed by constant improvement. A collection of Bourgogne wines that have aged along with the restaurant await the discerning tippler.

Name: Pizzeria Bella Napoli
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Neapolitan landscapes adorning the walls and Italian paintings decorating the interior conjure up the atmosphere of southern Italy. Tetsuya Ikeda, owner-chef of this Naples-style pizzeria, knows Naples well. Signature dishes are the three types of Margherita pizza. Using mozzarella from Italy, Hokkaido and Okayama lets guests compare the flavours of each region. True to the spirit of craftsmanship he learned in Italy, Ikeda tends to his wood-fired oven with passion.

Name: bistro simba
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Visiting France in the 2000s, chef Kikuchi was deeply impressed with the ‘bistronomy’ that was sweeping Paris at the time. He made up his mind to focus on this fusion of casual bistro fare with refined gastronomy. Bouillabaisse rich in the flavour of shrimp and Paris-Brest, a pastry, are prepared with loving memory of Kikuchi’s mentor. Committed to “simple, aromatic food with friendly service”, Kikuchi is moving forward.

Name: Nakatogawa
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: At this restaurant, you’ll find a blend of Japanese and traditional Italian dishes. The owner-chef trained extensively in Italian cuisine before opening his own restaurant. Standard menu items include caprese and several kinds of handmade pasta. He also prepares dishes he enjoyed as a child, such as shiraae, nimono and rice cooked in an earthenware pot. Being able to enjoy genuine dishes in a casual izakaya-like atmosphere is also appealing.

Name: Tempura Abe Hacchometen
FacilitiesAndServices: Air conditioning,American Express credit card,Counter dining,Credit card / Debit card accepted,Diners Club credit card,JCB,Mastercard credit card,Visa credit card
Description: Saburo Abe has built his life on tempura. He’s confident in his experience saying, “The secret to delicious taste is in the thickness of the batter”. His speciality is kakiage made with plenty of shrimp. The many options include Edomae seafood such as anago and big-eyed flathead and Kaga vegetables. Coated in thin batter, they’re lightly fried in a blend of mostly cottonseed oil. Enjoy the expert skill.

Name: Seki Hanare
